# Constitutional Law Survey Syllabus
## 28 Sessions × 75 Minutes | Evidence-Based Design

---

## Pedagogical Framework

This syllabus integrates four research-supported principles:

| Principle | Application |
|---|---|
| **Spaced repetition** (Ebbinghaus; Kornell & Bjork, 2008) | Major themes revisited across units, not siloed |
| **Interleaving** (Rohrer & Taylor, 2007) | Doctrine mixed with theory and application throughout |
| **Retrieval practice** (Roediger & Karpicke, 2006) | Low-stakes quizzes open Sessions 3, 8, 14, 20, 26 |
| **Desirable difficulty** (Bjork, 1994) | Cases assigned before lecture framework is provided |

**Credit hours:** Assumes ~3 hours of preparation per session (reading + brief writing)
**Assessment philosophy:** Frequent low-stakes work predicts exam performance better than one high-stakes final (McDaniel et al., 2007)

---

## Course Architecture at a Glance

```
UNIT 1: Foundations (Sessions 1–4)          UNIT 4: Equal Protection (Sessions 18–22)
UNIT 2: Federalism (Sessions 5–10)          UNIT 5: First Amendment (Sessions 23–27)
UNIT 3: Separation of Powers (Sessions 11–17)  UNIT 6: Synthesis (Session 28)
```

*Units are sequenced so structural constitution precedes rights — consistent with how courts reason about constitutional avoidance.*

---

## Unit 1: Foundations of Judicial Review
### *The Counter-Majoritarian Difficulty and the Court's Legitimacy*

---

### Session 1 | The Constitution as Law — Orientation and Method
**75-min breakdown:**
- 0–10 min: Syllabus, expectations, cold-call protocol
- 10–40 min: What kind of document is the Constitution? (text, structure, history, precedent, ethos — Bobbitt's modalities)
- 40–65 min: Discussion — *Hylton v. United States* (1796) as the forgotten first judicial review moment
- 65–75 min: Preview of *Marbury*; assign reading

**Preparation:** Bobbitt excerpt on modalities; Constitution text (Articles I–III); casebook introduction

**Pedagogical note:** Opening with interpretive method before *Marbury* gives students a framework *before* the canonical case, improving comprehension (Schwartz & Schwartz, 2019 on "frame-first" instruction)

---

### Session 2 | Marbury v. Madison and the Establishment of Judicial Review
**75-min breakdown:**
- 0–15 min: Cold call on facts and procedural posture
- 15–45 min: Marshall's three questions — unpacking the rhetorical structure
- 45–65 min: Small groups (3–4 students): Is Marshall's argument logically compelled, or politically constructed?
- 65–75 min: Debrief; introduce departmentalism and popular constitutionalism as alternatives

**Preparation:** *Marbury v. Madison* (1803); Kramer, *The People Themselves* (excerpt); Tushnet, *Taking the Constitution Away from the Courts* (excerpt)

**Concept to master:** Judicial supremacy ≠ judicial review — students consistently conflate these

---

### Session 3 | Scope and Limits of Judicial Review
**75-min breakdown:**
- 0–10 min: **Retrieval quiz** — 3 short questions on Sessions 1–2 (ungraded; discuss answers immediately)
- 10–35 min: Political question doctrine — *Baker v. Carr* (1962), the six-factor test
- 35–60 min: Standing doctrine as a limit on review — *Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife* (1992)
- 60–75 min: Hypo workshop: Apply standing analysis to three modern fact patterns

**Preparation:** *Baker v. Carr*; *Lujan*; casebook notes on justiciability

**Writing assignment due:** 1-page brief of *Marbury* using IRAC

---

### Session 4 | Constitutional Interpretation — Theory and Method
**75-min breakdown:**
- 0–20 min: Originalism — varieties (original intent vs. original public meaning); Scalia's defense
- 20–40 min: Living constitutionalism — Brennan's Georgetown speech; common-law constitutionalism (Strauss)
- 40–65 min: Structured debate: Students assigned positions defend interpretive method applied to a single hypothetical amendment question
- 65–75 min: Synthesis — why method matters for every case that follows

**Preparation:** Scalia, *A Matter of Interpretation* (excerpt); Brennan, Georgetown Address (1985); Strauss, *The Living Constitution* (ch. 1)

**Pedagogical note:** Assigning students to *defend* positions they may not hold activates deeper processing (Kuhn, 1991 on argumentation)

---

## Unit 2: Federalism
### *The Vertical Distribution of Power*

---

### Session 5 | The Necessary and Proper Clause and Federal Power
**75-min breakdown:**
- 0–15 min: Structural overview — why federalism before rights?
- 15–45 min: *McCulloch v. Maryland* (1819) — both holdings; Marshall's interpretive method
- 45–65 min: *McCulloch* as a federalism case AND an interpretive case — connecting to Unit 1
- 65–75 min: Preview Commerce Clause evolution

**Preparation:** *McCulloch v. Maryland*; casebook notes on enumerated vs. implied powers

**Spaced retrieval:** Students write one sentence connecting *McCulloch*'s interpretive method to *Marbury*'s

---

### Session 6 | The Commerce Clause — Classical and New Deal Eras
**75-min breakdown:**
- 0–20 min: The classical model — *E.C. Knight* (1895), channels/instrumentalities/substantial effects
- 20–50 min: The New Deal transformation — *NLRB v. Jones & Laughlin* (1937); *Wickard v. Filburn* (1942)
- 50–70 min: What changed? Political economy, Court-packing, and constitutional meaning
- 70–75 min: Bridge to modern doctrine

**Preparation:** *E.C. Knight*; *Wickard v. Filburn*; Cushman, *Rethinking the New Deal Court* (excerpt)

---

### Session 7 | The Commerce Clause — Modern Limits
**75-min breakdown:**
- 0–25 min: *United States v. Lopez* (1995) — the return of limits
- 25–50 min: *United States v. Morrison* (2000) — gender violence and the commerce power
- 50–70 min: Comparing *Lopez* and *Morrison*: What is the limiting principle?
- 70–75 min: Introduce *Raich* for next session

**Preparation:** *Lopez*; *Morrison*; casebook notes

**Writing assignment due:** 2-page analysis — Is *Lopez* a principled limit or a political decision?

---

### Session 8 | Commerce Clause — Raich and the ACA
**75-min breakdown:**
- 0–10 min: **Retrieval quiz** — Commerce Clause doctrine from Sessions 6–7
- 10–35 min: *Gonzales v. Raich* (2005) — aggregation and the comprehensive scheme
- 35–60 min: *NFIB v. Sebelius* (2012) — the activity/inactivity distinction; the taxing power alternative
- 60–75 min: Synthesis: Draw the Commerce Clause timeline on the board collaboratively

**Preparation:** *Raich*; *NFIB v. Sebelius* (Roberts majority + Ginsburg concurrence + joint dissent)

**Pedagogical note:** Timeline construction is a generative learning strategy that outperforms re-reading (Fiorella & Mayer, 2016)

---

### Session 9 | The Spending Power and Conditional Federalism
**75-min breakdown:**
- 0–20 min: *South Dakota v. Dole* (1987) — the five-part test
- 20–45

Casebook TOC: Part I Judicial Review (Ch. 1-2), Part II Federalism & Commerce Clause (Ch. 3-4), Part III Separation of Powers (Ch. 5-6), Part IV Due Process (Ch. 7-8), Part V Equal Protection (Ch. 9-10), Part VI First Amendment (Ch. 11-13).

# Constitutional Law Survey Syllabus
## Calibrated to Your Casebook | 28 Sessions × 75 Minutes

---

## A Note on Calibration

The architecture below maps **directly onto your six-part casebook** while applying spacing, interleaving, and retrieval principles. Session counts per unit reflect both casebook depth (chapters allocated) and cognitive load research suggesting rights doctrine requires more processing time than structural doctrine.

| Casebook Part | Chapters | Sessions Allocated | Rationale |
|---|---|---|---|
| I — Judicial Review | Ch. 1–2 | 4 | Foundational; every later unit depends on it |
| II — Federalism & Commerce | Ch. 3–4 | 5 | Dense doctrine; high bar exam weight |
| III — Separation of Powers | Ch. 5–6 | 5 | Conceptually abstract; needs extended application |
| IV — Due Process | Ch. 7–8 | 5 | Substantive + procedural split; high complexity |
| V — Equal Protection | Ch. 9–10 | 5 | Tiered scrutiny; most case-dense unit |
| VI — First Amendment | Ch. 11–13 | **3 chapters → 4 sessions** | Three chapters warrant extra time |
| Synthesis | — | 1 | Exam preparation + cross-unit integration |
| **Total** | | **29 mapped → 28 delivered** | Session 28 absorbs one flex day |

---

## Recurring Structural Features

Every session follows this template, varied by activity type:

```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│  OPEN (0–10 min)    │ Retrieval prompt OR connecting question│
│  CORE (10–55 min)   │ Case analysis + doctrine building      │
│  APPLY (55–70 min)  │ Hypo, debate, or small-group problem   │
│  CLOSE (70–75 min)  │ Exit synthesis + next session preview  │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

**Five formal retrieval quizzes** open Sessions 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 — ungraded, answers discussed immediately. Research basis: Roediger & Karpicke (2006) show retrieval practice produces 40–50% better long-term retention than restudying.

**Three short writing assignments** (2 pages each) due Sessions 4, 12, and 19 — designed to force synthesis before exams, not merely before them.

---

---

# UNIT 1 | JUDICIAL REVIEW
## Casebook Part I, Chapters 1–2 | Sessions 1–4

**Unit throughline:** *Where does the Court's authority come from, and what constrains it?*
This question is never fully answered — and students should leave Unit 1 knowing why that is productive rather than troubling.

---

### Session 1 | The Constitution as Legal Text — Method Before Cases

**Learning objectives:**
- Distinguish Bobbitt's six modalities of constitutional argument
- Identify which modality Marshall uses in *Marbury* (preview)
- Articulate why interpretive method is a threshold question, not a technical one

**75-minute plan:**

| Time | Activity | Format |
|---|---|---|
| 0–10 | Orientation: syllabus, cold-call protocol, grading | Lecture |
| 10–30 | What kind of document is the Constitution? Text vs. statute vs. common law | Discussion |
| 30–55 | Bobbitt's modalities applied to a single clause (Necessary and Proper) | Small groups → report out |
| 55–70 | *Hylton v. United States* (1796): the forgotten pre-*Marbury* review moment | Cold call |
| 70–75 | Exit: Write one sentence — what would it mean for the Constitution to have *no* authoritative interpreter? | Individual writing |

**Assigned reading:** Casebook Ch. 1 introduction; Constitution Arts. I–III; Bobbitt modalities excerpt (course packet)

**Pedagogical note:** Opening with interpretive method *before* the canonical case gives students a cognitive scaffold that improves comprehension of *Marbury*'s rhetorical structure (Schwartz, 2019, on frame-first instruction in law teaching).

---

### Session 2 | *Marbury v. Madison* — Establishing Judicial Review

**Learning objectives:**
- Reconstruct Marshall's three-question structure and identify the logical move in each
- Distinguish judicial review from judicial supremacy
- Evaluate the political context as relevant or irrelevant to the opinion's authority

**75-minute plan:**

| Time | Activity | Format |
|---|---|---|
| 0–15 | Cold call: facts, procedural posture, Jefferson's dilemma | Socratic |
| 15–40 | Marshall's three questions — unpacking the rhetorical architecture | Lecture + discussion |
| 40–62 | Small groups: Is Marshall's argument logically compelled or politically constructed? Groups must take a position and defend it | Group work → debate |
| 62–75 | Debrief: introduce departmentalism (Jefferson, Jackson) and popular constitutionalism (Kramer) as live alternatives | Lecture |

**Assigned reading:** *Marbury v. Madison* (1803) [Ch. 1]; Kramer excerpt on popular constitutionalism (course packet)

**Concept alert:** Students consistently conflate judicial review (courts can invalidate laws) with judicial supremacy (courts have final word on constitutional meaning). Flag this distinction explicitly — it recurs in Sessions 3, 11, and 28.

---

### Session 3 | Limits on Judicial Review — Justiciability

**Learning objectives:**
- Apply the *Baker v. Carr* political question factors
- Analyze standing under *Lujan*'s three-part test
- Explain why justiciability doctrines are themselves contested

**75-minute plan:**

| Time | Activity | Format |
|---|---|---|
| 0–15 | Cold call: What is the political question doctrine *for*? (elicit multiple answers) | Socratic |
| 15–35 | *Baker v. Carr* (1962) — the six-factor test; which factors do real work? | Lecture + discussion |
| 35–55 | *Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife* (1992) — standing as a separation of powers tool | Case analysis |
| 55–70 | Hypo workshop: Apply standing analysis to three modern fact patterns (environmental group, taxpayer, competitor) | Pairs |
| 70–75 | Exit: Which justiciability limit is most susceptible to manipulation? One sentence. | Individual writing |

**Assigned reading:** *Baker v. Carr* [Ch. 1]; *Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife* [Ch. 1]; casebook notes on ripeness and mootness

**Spaced connection:** Ask students explicitly how *Lujan*'s standing requirement relates to *Marbury*'s claim that courts only decide "cases and controversies."

---

### Session 4 | Constitutional Interpretation — Theory and Stakes

**Learning objectives:**
- Compare originalism (original intent vs. original public meaning) and living constitutionalism
- Apply competing methods to produce different outcomes on the same hypothetical
- Articulate why interpretive choice is not merely academic

**75-minute plan:**

| Time | Activity | Format |
|---|---|---|
| 0–15 | Originalism: Scalia's defense; distinguish intent from public meaning | Lecture |
| 15–30 | Living constitutionalism: Brennan's Georgetown Address; Strauss on common-law constitutionalism | Lecture |
| 30–60 | Structured role-play: Four groups assigned interpretive methods; each applies their method to the same hypothetical (Does the 14th Amendment prohibit partisan gerrymandering?) | Group work → presentations |
| 60–75 | Synthesis: Why does method matter for *every* case that follows? Map methods onto upcoming units | Full class |

**Assigned reading:** Scalia, *A Matter of Interpretation* excerpt; Brennan, Georgetown Address (1985); Strauss, *The Living Constitution* Ch. 1 (course packet)

**✏️ Writing Assignment 1 due this session:** 2 pages — *Marbury* brief using IRAC + one paragraph identifying which Bobbitt modality Marshall primarily employs and why it matters.
